headline: FedEx sues US for refund on Trump's emergency tariffs
summary:
STORY: FedEx on Monday filed a lawsuit in the U.S. Court of International Trade seeking a refund for President Donald Trump's emergency tariffs.

In the suit, the global transportation company named U.S. Customs and Border Protection, agency commissioner Rodney Scott and the United States of America as defendants.

It says it seeks "a full refund from the defendants of International Emergency Economic Powers Act duties" paid to the United States.

FedEx and its logistics arm served as importer of record on goods subject to the IEEPA tariffs.

The Memphis-based company did not provide the dollar value of the refund it is seeking, and none of the parties immediately replied to a request for comment.

But the move is one of the highest profile attempts to recover funds since the U.S. Supreme Court last week deemed the levies illegal.

More than $175 billion in U.S. tariff collections are subject to potential refunds according to Penn-Wharton Budget Model economists.

Meanwhile, Trump on Monday warned countries against backing away from recently negotiated trade deals with the U.S.

He wrote on Truth Social that "Any Country that wants to 'play games' with the ridiculous supreme court decision, especially those that have 'Ripped Off' the U.S.A. for years, and even decades, will be met with a much higher Tariff, and worse, than that which they just recently agreed to. BUYER BEWARE!!!"

Trump said he also may impose license fees on trading partners.

content.title: FedEx sues US for refund on Trump's emergency tariffs

headline: FedEx joins other US companies in seeking a refund after Trump tariffs are ruled illegal
summary: FedEx is suing the U.S. government, requesting a full refund on what it paid for tariffs set by President Donald Trump last year after the Supreme Court ruled that the tariffs are illegal.  FedEx said in a filing with the U.S. Court of International Trade that they have ‚Äúsuffered injury‚Äù from having to pay the tariffs and that the relief they're seeking from the court would redress those injuries.  Other companies have already launched efforts to recoup costs from the illegal tariffs, including large U.S. corporations like Costco and Revlon.

content.title: FedEx joins other US companies in seeking a refund after Trump tariffs are ruled illegal
content.summary: FedEx is suing the U.S. government, requesting a full refund on what it paid for tariffs set by President Donald Trump last year after the Supreme Court ruled that the tariffs are illegal.  FedEx said in a filing with the U.S. Court of International Trade that they have ‚Äúsuffered injury‚Äù from having to pay the tariffs and that the relief they're seeking from the court would redress those injuries.  Other companies have already launched efforts to recoup costs from the illegal tariffs, including large U.S. corporations like Costco and Revlon.

headline: FedEx is latest company to sue Trump admin. for tariff refunds
summary: FedEx (FDX) has filed a lawsuit seeking refunds on President Trump's tariff policies, while Costco (COST) and Revlon have also staked claims following a recent Supreme Court decision that struck down the administration's sweeping tariffs. The ruling did not address whether companies would be reimbursed. Sevens Report Research founder Tom Essaye joins the live show with Yahoo Finance Markets and Data Editor Jared Blikre and Yahoo Finance Senior Markets Reporter Ines Ferr√© to break down what the tariff uncertainty means for companies, consumers, and markets. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid.
